Posts.Title: Feeling so Unsettled Kandy Kjones13

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2014 02:07PM smiley47 wrote: Hi Chris: Sorry to hear your suffering with so much pain, I hope the doctors find a medication to take away the pain. I wish you did not have to wait for the results that just adds to the stress. I had similar pain this last month on falsodex after being injected with my third infusion. I had sciatic nerve pain and could barely walk for three weeks, started loosing weight and sweated awfully.  I had a scan and it showed progression and the doctor gave me morphine for the pain; I looked at deaths door.  The day after seeing the doctor I awoke to no pain or symptoms that had been plaquing me for three weeks; I think I had a reaction to the faslodex, my doctor was a little taken aback when I told her the next day I needed no pain meds and all symptoms had disappeared.  I am now back on taxol chemo and feeling so much better.

Posts.Content: Jun 24, 2015 08:10AM smiley47 wrote: Hi there: I am on third day of full brain radiation, very tired, very slow but better than last two days due to tiredness and inability to focus. See onc today I presume she will give me the hard hitting news like the first rad doc did 8-12 mnths. Given up trying to hope, given up trying to stay positive it just is what it is. Maybe I will live a bit more who knows. Sorry to be a downer, with a seven year old it must be hard, mine are 17-13yrs. I wish and hope they can sloww this c down so we can raise are little ones. Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2015 08:13AM smiley47 wrote: Hi Catesmom: I read your post about headaches but I did not have that symptom; sorry, maybe someone else can comment. I have been feeling slow, sluggish and weary. Sleepy if I'm sitting around with an aggitated feeling mixed in. Each day gets better but I take hydromorphine and anti anxiety meds and that helps a lot. Sleep from 9 till 3 and then watch some netflix and have a tea with meds. This helps me sleep till 8. Thank you everyone for your input to my situation and the medical situations you've been through really helps. MandyMoo thank you so much for your post my daughter just got up looking stressed and sad and I told her about your experience and it cheered her to no end. I wonder if your leps were in the brain fluid and nerves as mine are. I have no symptoms and never had from my cancer it just keeps popping up every 8-12 weeks on scans, only when I was newly diagnosed did i have bone pain slightly. They are supposed to be tiny in the brain too

Posts.Title: PET scan says NED ... 6 years strong JeninMichigan roberta37

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2014 12:19PM smiley47 wrote: Hi: I had a similar experience to your mother in the two years I took Aromisin I had severe leg pain that the doctors told me to take pain meds for; advil worked best. Then in the summer I started to get lots of pain in the ribs and was diagnosed with bone mets to the ribs, I was put on femara and started to have terrible flu symptoms and pains in my body that were unbearable; the doctors and nurses did not know why I had so much pain and flu like symptoms.  My onc thought it was my bodies way of interpreting the cancer. I would live with hot water bottles and advil at double doses every four to six hours. The pains in my bones would hurt for three weeks and then move to another area but the flu symptoms were continuous; so bad I would cry in desperation and weariness. A few months later the mets to the bones and liver were getting worse and so I was switched to another chemo drug and the flu symptoms started to go away over a two week period but the bones still hurt and eventually the scans showed more progression of the bones. I found the cancer web sites for stage 4 were very happy with the femara medicine in comparison the stage 3 threads of pain in the bones and the flu symptoms; which gave me hope it was the femara drug and nothing worse. When I met with my radiologist a couple of weeks ago he said that it is a well known fact that if you have extensive bone mets and take femara then you can have extreme pain from the drug in the bones. I wish I had spoken to him when I had these symptoms but thought my onc or family doctor would be open and knowledable enough to pass this on. They would only offer me more pain meds such as morphine that had no effect on the pain and symptoms but advil worked wonders in comparison. Another symptom I had on Femara was the feeling of dizzyiness and feeling like I could have something like a panic attack; it was all very disturbing and life altering. I hope you find help and move on from these symptoms. I noticed you are in Ontario the same as I and if you would like to email me privately you are welcome too. smiley47

Posts.Title: Survival after detection of brain mets? MarshaMay embmom

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2015 02:33PM smiley47 wrote:  Welcome to the group, you will hopefully find help and comfort from the Other breast cancer survivors. You stated your situation so well, I remember saying the same thing to my radiologist. I just wanted a treatment to work so I could catch my breathe and find my feet but instead I went through the anti hormonals quickly and had lots of progression. On femera I was bed bound for three months, did chemo(taxol) got better everything shrunk so I had a chemo break on faslodex and was bed bound again with lots of progression and now I am on chemo for life. The oncologists just give the information as it is and its hard to hear and absorb, i'm still trying to find an anxiety medicine, no luck so far so I just live in a state of high anxiety, fear and worry and some times I get worn out thinking about my sitation and feel numb. What will be will be and I go about my chores. Scans are paticularly hard so if you can take a friend that helps, avoid reading the doom and gloom posts and look for positive experiences to gain strength from. Someone just posted about twice being on deaths door and rebounded each time to the shock of her doctors. Some say its not how much cancer you have but a matter of findingthe right treatment plan. Good luck and keep us posted
Posts.Title: Feels like it is all happening sooo fast! Know what I mean? mtmom Bestbird

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2014 09:10PM smiley47 wrote: Hi there: Sorry to hear your news but I would take the advice of your doctor and be grateful it is found and they are going to remove it and move forward for you. Your doctor sounds nice and comforting. I think when we have stage four we would be daft to think it only in one place, sometimes it takes time to show up else where and the key to all of this terrible cancer curse is that they can control and deal with the ovaries and uterus and hopefully it has not gone anywhere else and your treatments will help you. Alison (Smiley47)
Posts.Title: saw onc today chris1959

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2014 05:06AM smiley47 wrote: Hi Helen: Just noticed your post about markers going up on chemo when you have just started new chemo, I do believe they can go up significantly because the chemo messes up our whole system. My chemo nurse told me that she sees regularly people start chemo with normal markers too have them shoot up and then eventually go down but not always within range for "normal" because of the drugs in the system not because of the cancer. My onc has stated this too and the last time I was on chemo they stayed outside normal range for the liver by 20 points to go within normal range once chemo stopped, which is what the onc thought would happen. Hope this helps , babbling a little, I hate email to explain myself.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2014 12:21AM smiley47 wrote: Thank you everyone for your kind words and encorougment. I went for a Heart Echo and they could not find anything wrong with heart and thought it was an error on the c-scan report. Then today I was in chemo getting my second Taxol when the chemo doctor came in(he also did the heart echo) and checked the c-scan for a comparison to his heart echo and found the tiniest pocket on the heart lining that is definately cancer, but barely visiable. He was shocked and was totally into the differences in the scans. I was totally shocked and now afraid again. I have so far not responded to femura and Xeloda; now I am worried the cancer is moving quickly and the Taxol wil not work.

My children help clean on the weekends, life skill training and I do not stand over them. I think this diagnosis has helped me not be so concerned about things not being perfect around me and I do not worry about certain situations that would in the past have bothered me, housework is way up on that list, especially with a dog and building construction all around me. The floors get cleaned once a week and really need to be done every other day with the mud the dog brings in but alas I cannot be bothered, so if I am wearing socks I walk over the dried mud spots of paw prints and theydisintegrate over time.

Posts.Content: Dec 11, 2014 10:31AM smiley47 wrote: Hi Ardmore: I had the same thing happen to me the anti hormonals did not work and each time we tried them I had progression to the origianal organ or bone or a new organ would show mets, very small but there. So we would change meds and the only one so far to work for me is taxol chemo. I have scans on 16 Dec and I am very worried about them but my blood counts are good. Try not to worry too much you do have lots of options and they have been caught the mets straight away because the docs are monitoring you carefully. Hugs

Posts.Title: Having a scan? Waiting on results? The waiting room is open! exbrnxgrl gramen

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2015 09:54AM smiley47 wrote: Welcome: I hope you find the ladies who have responded so far to your concerns have helped to calm your fears and have given you positive goals of expectations that I find far more reassuring then the onc's. I have liver mets and mets in several other places that are hopefully being controlled with chemo(taxol) did all the anti hormonals with lots of progression and was bedridden by their side effects but chemo makes me feel better and I function well through the day. I am now 16mths since being rediagnosed and wonder why they dont scan more and be more proactive with the lower stages but here we are. We all suffer from fear and no one can predict how you will respond to the treatments, thats why this is a great place to come especially at 2am when the fear can be worst and then I find a reassuring post and I settle back down to sleep. Good luck with your medical program and remember when the onc saus life long chemo, they are just preparing you, you will notice women who have done chemo and then had chemo breaks for over several years but the doctors dont tell you that, false hope I presume for some patients
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with Liver cancer Scrappygrl Scrappygrl

Posts.Content: May 1, 2014 09:52AM smiley47 wrote: Hi Jaxzgirl: I am sorry to hear that you have joined us and yes you will be in shock. The doctors I have dealt with have been very abrupt and factual. Sometimes they are discussing my situation in a hip/happy manner that I feel is bizarre and asking for my opinion on treatment options that I do not feel in a place to comment on but they do want my input. I am still trying to cope with the cancer stage I am at and the standard of communication I have to navigate when I do not feel secure or aware of all the facts. I have found this site to be very helpful and positive in helping me navigate the negative treatment I get from the medical community or the lack of information I receive in a positive aspects of the treatments we undergo; I feel they always want to tell me the worse case. I was also told after two drugs did not work for me that I would be on chemo for the rest of my life and that was taxol for three weeks on and one week off but after four treatments I am going on a trail drug. So now I am worried that will not work and I will have to ride another wave of uncertainty. It is a roller coaster for you emotionally but just remember when you are unsure ask for help from the girls and someone will be out there going through or has been through what you are experiencing and they will reach out to you and help you.   Smiley47
